source: Public Podcast – Tech Career Talks: “Planning Your Engineer Career Path”

level_1: This episode explains why mapping your career as an engineer matters early on.
It introduces the idea of short-term goals (intern, junior dev) and bigger goals (senior, lead).
level_2: Hosts highlight defining milestones like mastering a language or building a project before a year ends.
They suggest picking roles that align with your interests—like mobile, backend, or ML.
level_3: Speakers describe designing a multi-year roadmap including tech skills, soft skills, and leadership development.
They discuss pivoting roles — e.g. transitioning from frontend to full-stack or backend.
level_4: Leads talk about aligning personal roadmaps with company goals and evolving industry trends like microservices or edge computing.
They discuss mentoring others and creating team-wide career templates.

level_1: A student chooses a summer internship in web development to gain relevant experience.
A beginner draws a timeline marking language learning and small app builds.
level_2: A junior dev sets a 6-month project goal like deploying a live app on cloud.
They track monthly progress and adjust if needed.
level_3: A mid-level engineer plans a 2-year path to become a tech lead or system architect.
They include mentorship, open-source contributions, and certifications.
level_4: A senior maps a team-building roadmap, identifying team skills gaps and planning workshops.
They create career progression tracks for their direct reports.

level_1: Interns follow roadmaps during onboarding programs.
level_2: Companies encourage juniors to set quarterly goals with their managers.
level_3: Mid-level devs develop personal growth plans tied to performance reviews.
level_4: Leaders design department-wide career frameworks aligned to business objectives.

level_1: Ask: Where do I see myself in 6 months?
level_2: Plan: What project or tool will help me reach that role?
level_3: Evaluate: Is this roadmap achievable and flexible?
level_4: Align: Does this plan match company strategy and technology trends?

level_1: Not planning anything and getting lost.
level_2: Setting unrealistic timelines without concrete steps.
level_3: Ignoring feedback from mentors or peers on roadmap ideas.
level_4: Sticking to a plan that no longer fits industry or team direction.

level_2: Name one milestone you can set for year one.
level_3: Why include mentorship in a mid-career plan?
level_4: How do you align your roadmap with business goals?

level_2: Write a project plan to launch an app this quarter.
level_3: Draft a 2-year career growth plan including leadership goals.
level_4: Design a career framework for your team or study group.

level_1: Don’t skip planning—start with a small goal.
level_2: Avoid vague plans like 'get better at coding'.
level_3: Never ignore feedback—review your roadmap regularly.
level_4: Avoid fixed plans—update based on team and industry changes.
